chapter.title: Tinkar Modeling Guide Introduction
chapter.para: This modeling guide establishes the process and outputs for modeling domain concepts in the Terminology Knowledge Architecture (Tinkar) specification. This guide does not encompass all the details and information about the Tinkar model. Therefore, it is encouraged to review the HL7 informative ballot before this guide.

section.title: What is Tinkar?
section.para: Tinkar is a logical model that aims to provide a foundation for a knowledge architecture that will integrate medical and laboratory terminologies like SNOMED CT®, LOINC®, RxNorm, etc. and local systems, to support clinical information that can communicate effectively across multiple systems.​ Tinkar is intended to support health care organizations’ standard terminology modules, value sets, and coding systems as well as local terms and equivalence mappings. It allows enterprises to extend their terminology standards and implement extensions quickly.

section.title: Why Tinkar?
section.para: Information systems that are used across the healthcare enterprise record and manage clinical data using clinical statements and clinical terminologies in non-standardized ways. Interoperability specifications aim to require terminology bindings to concepts, code systems, and reusable value sets. Currently, there is variation in clinical data exchange across the enterprise, as existing payloads and clinical statements use inconsistent and highly variable enterprise terminologies. The management of the concepts, code systems, and value sets is non-trivial because developers, implementers, and end users are forced to manage “unnecessary complexity.” For example:

listitem.para: Representation of medications: RxNorm codes overlap with CVX codes. Investigational vaccines from the FDA are not represented in RxNorm, CVX, or SNOMED CT®.
Representation of COVID-19 result codes are inconsistent and are not equivalent (e.g., detected, undetected, positive, negative, etc.).

chapter.title: Tinkar Logical Model
chapter.para:
The Tinkar logical model consists of three different attributes: concepts, patterns, and semantics . The model can represent any knowledge standard, while still allowing for transparency of the data and traceability.
Tinkar Logical Model
Before modeling a data set in the logical Tinkar model, the current Tinkar logical model starter data concepts, patterns and semantics should be understood. The goal is to use what already exists in Tinkar as much as possible and only create new concepts/patterns/ semantics when needed. This section gives a basic rundown of the Tinkar logical model. The full description of the logical model is in the HL7 ballot, linked in the Introduction of this document.

section.title: Components
section.para: All components in Tinkar are uniquely identified using UUIDs. A component will be represented by an array of UUIDs with at least one UUID but can be represented by more than one UUID in the case of a concept being derived from multiple sources. For example, the concept Acetaminophen (which exists in SNOMED CT®, LOINC®, and RxNorm) could have a UUID from each terminology and be represented as an array of UUIDs for this single concept within a Tinkar implementation. Concepts, patterns, and semantics are types of components.

section.title: Concepts
section.para: A concept in Tinkar is a component identified using Universally Unique Identifiers (UUIDs) and a STAMP. It contains no information other than what’s contained within the STAMP. Concepts have emergent meaning. For example, Acetaminophen can be represented by attaching the description “Acetaminophen” to a concept. The concept has no meaning without additional information. Additional information is provided by semantics. The specific meaning, purpose, and data elements of a semantic are defined by a pattern.

For example, for the concept of Acute Pelvic Pain, there needs to be information to describe it, which is all asserted by one or more semantics of one or more patterns (possibly multiple descriptions, a logical definition, …). Examples of that assertion include descriptions of the concept, the fully qualified name, and unique relationships related to the concept.

section.title: Patterns
section.para:
A pattern defines a meaning and purpose for its semantics, and a set of fields, which also have a specific a purpose, and a meaning, in addition to a datatype. Every semantic of a pattern exactly follows that pattern. These fields describe what type of information and what format the data in a semantic following this pattern will be. Using the pattern, semantics with varying fields and field types can be specified to represent any structure needed to provide meaning to a component. The table below shows the Description Pattern. Description Pattern
Description Pattern
Semantic Meaning Description Semantic
Semantic Purpose Description Semantic
Field 1: Language
Meaning Language for Description
Purpose Language
Field Type Component Field
Field 2: Description
Meaning Text for Description
Purpose Description
Field Type String
Field 3: Description Case Significance
Meaning Description Case Significance
Purpose Description Case Significance
Field Type Component Field
Field 4: Description Type
Meaning Description Type
Purpose Description Type
Field Type Component Field
The meaning and purpose concepts shown in the above table for the Description Pattern also are concepts in Tinkar with definitions. The table below shows the definition for the meaning and purpose concepts from the Description Pattern table.

table.title: Description Pattern Meaning and Purpose Concepts

para.emphasis: Description Pattern Semantic Meaning and Purpose

row.entry: Purpose and meaning for the description pattern and dialect patterns
The semantic value indicating which language is used in the description text
Specifies the language of the description text.
Captures the human readable text for a description in Komet
Human readable text for a concept

entry.emphasis: Field 3: Description Case Significance Meaning and Purpose

row.entry: Specifies how to handle the description text in terms of case sensitivity

entry.emphasis: Field 4: Description Type Meaning and Purpose

row.entry: Specifying what type of description, e.g., fully qualified or regular, etc.

section.title: Semantics
section.para: To give computer-processable meaning to components, Tinkar uses Semantics. A Semantic is a component containing a set of fields about the subject (the meaning and purpose defined by its pattern). A Semantic adds meaning to the components it references through the fields it contains. A Semantic supports the specification of value sets, compositional definitions, and other components requiring internal structure, and it specifies the nature of the compositional relationship explicitly.

section.title: STAMP
section.para: The STAMP in the Tinkar Reference Model allows for capturing a complete change record of all changes to a component including the Status, Time, Author, Module, and Path. As a model changes and evolves, with each change made in a component, a new change record is created for that change and a new STAMP Coordinate is assigned. To track information like when and who made the changes, a STAMP is assigned to each version, so the history is recorded and preserved.
The following describes each of these attributes:

Status – A status is identified by a Concept and may be annotated with additional information. For example, inactive or active. The tables below show the parent and children Concepts aligned to Status.

row.entry: The status represented by the STAMP (Active, Cancelled, Inactive, Premundane, Withdrawn)
Concept used to represent a status for the default status. It’s the original default status when creating a Concept that has not transitioned to a different status.

In the Premundane status, components can move to the Cancelled or Active statuses. Since primordial components were never committed to a database there would be no reason to move them to the Inactive or Withdrawn statuses.
When a new component has been created but nothing is assigned nor has it been approved, it would have a Premundane status.

Concept used to represent a status for components that are canceled – Canceled means it was never successfully committed to the database, and so this state would be local only, and also transient… It will eventually be removed from memory and from the database and will not propagate from one database to another.
The Cancelled status is a terminal status, meaning it cannot be moved from the Cancelled status back to a different status.

listitem.para: Created initially in the Premundane status but is deemed unnecessary

entry.para: It would be moved to Cancelled status.

row.entry: Concept used to represent a status for components that are active.
In the Active status, components can move to the Inactive status if a component is no longer active or the Withdraw status, if the component is realized to be a mistake.
A component that was in Premundane status that has been fully reviewed and vetted will move to the Active status.
Concept used to represent a status for components that are no longer active.

In the Inactive status, components can move to the Withdraw status, if the component is realized to be a mistake. In special circumstances with a good business reason, components may be moved from Inactive back to Active.
A component that is no longer needed that was in the Active status. For example, the model changed or was made obsolete by a new component.

Concept used to represent a status for components that are withdrawn. Withdrawn indicates that a component was successfully released, but that the component’s release was a mistake, and all references to a withdrawn component should be reassigned.
The Withdrawn status is a terminal status.
If a component was accidentally created and committed to the Active status, it would be moved to the Withdrawn status.

section.para: When representing a new data set using the Tinkar Reference Model, only the status values above are allowed and must follow the business rules defined. The business rules do not account for the accidental moving of a component. The diagram below shows the mapping between each status.

If the data set has additional status values, for example the LOINC® Discouraged Status, they should be represented via an additional Pattern and Semantic. The STAMP status values should never be extended beyond the provided starter set. In the LOINC® example, the status would be Active since it was in use, but a Semantic would be assigned to say it was Discouraged to take note of that extra information.
Time – The timestamp is captured with precision and a time zone. The table below shows the parent Concept aligned to Time.

entry.para: The timestamp is captured with precision and a time zone

section.para: Author – The author is identified by a Concept and may be annotated with more information and represents the change's author. The tables below show the parent Concept aligned to Author.

entry.para: The author is identified by a Concept, and may be annotated with other identifying information and represents the author responsible for authoring the change

section.para: Module – This is the assignment to the appropriate terminology (e.g. LOINC®) or terminology component (SNOMED CT®). A module is identified by a Concept and may be annotated with additional information. The tables below show the parent and children Concepts aligned to Module.

row.entry: A module is identified by a Concept and may be annotated with additional information such as organizing content for maintenance and publication purposes.

The base/foundational/default module assigned prior to creating other model/module Concepts, the primordial module is reserved for starter set information that all Tinkar Reference Models require. Information that is specific to a particular data set (i.e., SNOMED CT® or LOINC®) should be contained in a module specific to that data set (i.e. a SNOMED CT® or LOINC® starter set module)

section.para: Path – Specification of version control within a development lifecycle, for example development, testing, staging, or production. A path is identified by a Concept and may be annotated with additional information. The tables below show the parent and children Concepts aligned to Path.

Path Parent Concept
Parent Concept Definition
Path A set of assets under version control that can be managed distinctly from other assets. Paths “branch” from other paths when established and can be “merged” with other paths as well.
Path Children Concepts in the starter set. Additional paths may be created as need to organize development activities appropriately for a particular purpose (sandbox paths, feature paths, …)
Children Concept Definition
Prerequisite Path A path that contains components that are shared across all paths and contain infrastructure components.
Sandbox Path A path “branch” for components under testing.
Development Path A path “branch” that specifies that the components are currently under development
Master Path A default path “branch” for components. This path represents those finalized or published components in production
The diagram below shows the relationship between different Paths. Path Diagram
The STAMP attributes are used to help describe versions of components. As a model changes and evolves, with each change made in a component, a new version is created for that change. To track information like when and who made the changes, a STAMP is assigned to each version, so the history is recorded and preserved.

section.title: STAMP Progression Examples in Component Versions
section.para: To understand how STAMP are being assigned to component versions, the following examples below illustrate how STAMP functions and the design process behind it.

section.title: Example 1: Proposing a New SNOMED CT® Regular Name (Synonym) Locally
section.para: In this example, a new Regular Name description to a SNOMED CT® Concept as a local extension is proposed. Since a new Semantic is being created, which is a component, the new component version needs a STAMP. In this example, the following parts are assigned:

row.entry: Status is set to Active since the Semantic should be active and visible.
The current date and time when the Semantic was created.
The specific user account as a Tinkar Concept should be assigned.
Local Extension Module to SNOMED CT®
This is a local extension not any official SNOMED CT® release.
This is a proposal for the new Semantic and not an official reviewed Semantic.

section.title: Example 2: Testing Different Pattern Designs for Approval and Moving Forward with One
section.para: In this example, three different Patterns to simulate storing experimental data in different ways are tested. Those can be sent off to another user and they decide which one they like best and propose to keep that one and get rid of the others.
To start out, all three different Patterns would have similar STAMP assignments:

row.entry: Status is set to Active since the Semantic should be active and visible.
The current date and time when the Semantic was created.
The specific user account as a Tinkar Concept should be assigned. For this example, “Author 1” is used.

entry.para: Unique Module to specify the domain or data set that is being used.
The proposed Patterns are just made for testing the data and not official or in progress yet.

section.para: A second person might then look at those testing Patterns and if they decide they like one design over the others, they can update the Patterns to new versions and reflect their decision in the STAMP for those Pattern versions.
The Pattern they would like to keep:

row.entry: Status is set to Active since the Semantic should be active and visible.
The current date and time when the Semantic was created.
The second person who chose the Pattern or “Author 2”.

entry.para: Unique Module to specify the domain or data set that is being used.

row.entry: The proposed Pattern now has moved into development and is waiting for official approval and review before it can potentially be moved to the “Master Path”.

section.para: The other Patterns they would like to remove:

row.entry: The status is changed to inactive since the users no longer want these Patterns and aren’t going to use them.
The current date and time when the Semantic was created.
The second person who chose the Pattern or “Author 2”.
Unique Module to specify the domain or data set being used. Remains the same.

entry.para: The proposed Patterns are still just testing Patterns and not official or in development.

section.title: Tinkar Representation Examples
section.para: The section below highlights examples of how common medical tests can be represented in Tinkar. The examples show how the tests, currently represented in both SNOMED CT® and LOINC® terminologies, can be modeled in the Tinkar Logical Model.

section.title: Example 1 - Urine Homocysteine
section.para: The figure below illustrates a Urine Homocysteine Test represented in the Tinkar Logical Model. The Concept contains both the description for the test as well as its corresponding UUID. This Concept serves as the subject for further classification. The Pattern uses field definitions to explain and categorize the corresponding Semantic fields. For example, LOINC® records the interval of time over which an observation was made. The time to conduct a Urine Homocysteine Test is 24 hours. Therefore, under the Time field definition within the LOINC® Pattern, the corresponding Semantic Field would be 24H. While there are separate Patterns and Semantics for both SNOMED CT® and LOINC® terminologies, they are both connected to the original Concept.

section.title: Example 2 - Substance Concentration of Glucose in Specimen at Point in Time
section.para: The below figure illustrates a Substance Concentration of Glucose in Specimen Test represented in the Tinkar Logical Model. The Concept contains both the description for the test as well as its corresponding UUID. This Concept serves as the subject for further classification. The Pattern uses field definitions to explain and categorize the corresponding Semantic fields. For example, this test involves measuring the concentration of glucose in a given specimen. Therefore, under the Method field definition within the SNOMED CT® Pattern, the corresponding semantic field would be Measurement – action. While there are separate Patterns and Semantics for both SNOMED CT® and LOINC® terminologies, they are both connected to the original Concept.

figure.title: Example 2: Substance Concentration of Glucose in Specimen in Tinkar

chapter.title: Modeling Principles
chapter.para: There are specific principles to try and follow while executing the modeling process. These principles are detailed below.

listitem.para: Encapsulate rather than specialize.: For example, if a device identifier is sourced from a database like the Global Unique Device Identification Database (GUDID), you would not create a new Pattern to handle it. You should continue to use the Identifier Pattern already created in GUDID, but instead create a new Pattern to add any additional information needed (i.e. Is it a Primary DI or a Secondary DI?, etc.) This new Pattern could then have Semantics referencing the identifier Semantic components to give meaning.

A Pattern/Field Definition cannot have the same purpose as its meaning.: In cases where a pattern has more than one field definition, we want the purpose and meaning to be unique for each field definition. If there is only one field definition it is okay if the meaning and purpose are the same but in general we want to be as specific here as possible since the reasoner looks at these purpose and meaning concepts to determine equivalence in patterns.

chapter.title: Creating a Representative Tinkar Model for a Dataset
chapter.para: Converting a domain data set into the Tinkar model involves several key steps. The sections below detail the current Tinkar starter data and the steps one will take to translate a dataset into the Tinkar logical model. Key Steps to Represent a Data Set in Tinkar

section.title: Defining The Data Elements
section.para: Once the current basic Tinkar Reference Model is understood, the data set’s required Patterns can be determined. Some Patterns will come from the current Tinkar starter set, other Patterns will be created specifically for the data set’s unique properties or may be reused from other systems such as SNOMED CT®, LOINC®, or RxNorm.

In preparation to model in Tinkar, there are two different ways to start: from an existing system’s data set like SNOMED CT®, LOINC®, or RxNorm or a new model using elements that might already exist and/or have brand new elements that need to be represented (e.g., LIDR). The differences between a predefined data set and a new data set are minimal. The main difference is, with a predefined data set, information about the model is usually well documented so identifying a unique list of data elements and definitions is more straight forward. With a new data set, unique data elements and definitions will take more time to validates.

The first step in modeling in Tinkar from any data set is analyzing the data set or source file that needs to be represented in Tinkar. The recommended starting point is pulling out all unique data fields in the data set or source file and giving them a meaning, purpose, and definition.

In general, the term meaning refers to the Concept or idea that a word, phrase, symbol, or other form of communication represents. Within the Tinkar Reference Model, "meaning" is applied to a field within a Semantic and indicates the type of information or data the field is designed to hold. For example, a field used to describe an SDO's website would have the Meaning of "URL." This implies that the field is meant to contain a URL, which is a specific type of data representing a web address.

The purpose within the Tinkar Reference Model refers to the specific role or function that a field within a Semantic is intended to serve. It provides a broader context for why the field and its data exist within the model. For example, in the field describing an SDO's website, the purpose is "Website." This indicates that the field's role is to provide the website address for the SDO, adding context to the meaning "URL.".

For a data set that is part of a well-established source such as RxNorm and SNOMED CT®, definitions of fields can typically be found in documentation online of the terminology. For a data set that is not well-established, the definitions might have to be created.

To show a practical example of a predefined data set, an image below shows a snippet of the LOINC®transformation. LOINC®is a predefined data set with definitions and fields listed in a source file. In this snippet, some of the unique LOINC®fields provided in the data set are added to an excel in preparation for a cross walk. The purpose, meaning, and definitions are added to give an example of what these definitions should be.
The example in the below screenshot, shows a row of LOINC®data that will be used to show how the data set was represented using the Description Semantics.
Once unique data elements have been recorded, the elements can be cross walked to current Tinkar semantics/ concepts/ patterns.

section.title: Determine Description Semantics
section.para: It is recommended to start with the description semantic and review the components and determine which of the fields in the data set being analyzed can be represented using the Tinkar description semantics. The Description Semantics are how names and definitions are assigned to components. The fields in the Description Pattern in Table 1 should be reviewed to determine what values/concepts to use in the data set being analyzed or if something new needs to be created. The meaning and purpose concepts are also below to reference are listed in Table 2.

To understand how this has been done before, examples of terminology snippets from SNOMED CT®, LOINC®, RxNorm, and LIDR are provided below. As the following sections walk through modeling the Description Semantic, these snippets will be referred to as examples for how to model certain fields.

section.title: Example 1: SNOMED CT Regular Name
section.para: The example in the below screenshot, shows a row of LOINC®data that will be used to show how the data set was represented using the Description Semantics.

section.title: Example 2: LOINC Long Common Name
section.para: The example in the below screenshot, shows a row of LOINC®data that will be used to show how the data set was represented using the Description Semantics.

section.title: Example 3: RxNorm Tallman Synonym
section.para: The example in the below screenshot, shows a row of RxNorm data that will be used to show how the data set was represented using the Description Semantics.

section.title: Example 4: LIDR Device Model
section.para: The example in the below screenshot, shows multiple rows in LIDR Data all corresponding to one Device. This data that will be used to show how the data set was represented using the Description Semantics for a Device concept.

section.title: Field 1: Language
section.para: A language Concept is assigned as the first field value for the Description Semantic. The language field's purpose is to identify the concept's language and description. The table below outlines the current available languages to select from. If the specific language concept does not exist in Tinkar, a new concept to represent that specific language will need to be added.

Concept Definition
English Language
A concept representing the English Language
Spanish Language A concept representing the Spanish Language
Chinese Language A concept representing the Chinese Language
Czech Language A concept representing the Czech Language
Danish Language A concept representing the Danish Language
Dutch Language A concept representing the Dutch Language
French Language A concept representing the French Language
German Language A concept representing the German Language
Irish Language A concept representing the Irish Language
Italian Language A concept representing the Italian Language
Korean Language A concept representing the Korean Language
Lithuanian Language A concept representing the Lithuanian Language
Polish Language A concept representing the Polish Language
Russian Language A concept representing the Russian Language
Swedish Language A concept representing the Swedish Language
Revisiting the examples provided above, the following representations and/or gaps were identified:

row.entry: From the SNOMED CT® export file, language Code can be represented by the language Concept. In this case, 'en' would be used for English.
From the LOINC® export file, the English version has been obtained, so all descriptions can be represented by the language Concept.
From the RxNorm export file, the English version has been obtained, so all descriptions can be represented by the language Concept and English can be used.
From the LIDR Excel File, the data was entered using the English Language, so all descriptions can be represented by the language Concept and English can be used.

section.para: No new concepts would need to be created since the above strings can be represented with what already exists in Tinkar.
If the data set has a language concept that currently is not in Tinkar, a new concept representing the new language will have to be created.

listitem.para: Give it the Fully Qualified name of the specific language the concept is representing.
In the Stated Definition, add an is-A relationship to language under the necessary set.

section.title: Field 2: Description String
section.para: The description string field is the literal string representation of the data, which is generally just the name of the element.

row.entry: The string value that represents the data.

section.para: Revisiting the examples provided above, the following representations were identified:

row.entry: From the SNOMED CT® export file, the string value of the Term field "Chronic lung disease" is taken to represent the Tinkar Description String value in the Description Semantic.

From the LOINC® export file, the string value of the Long Common Name "Meadow Fescue IgG Ab [Units/volume] in Serum" is taken to represent the Tinkar Description String value in the Description Semantic.

From the RxNorm export file, the string value of the text inside the quotations "amLODIPine (as amLODIPine besilate) 5 MG / HCTZ 25 MG / olmesartan medoxomil 40 MG Oral Tablet" is taken to represent the Tinkar Description String value in the Description Semantic.

From the LIDR Data File, the String Value of the text inside the Model cell “BD SARS-CoV-2/Flu for BD MAX System” is the description which can be represented using the Tinkar Description String value in the Description Semantic.

section.para: No new concepts would need to be created since the above strings can be represented with what already exists in Tinkar.

section.title: Field 3: Description Case Significance
section.para: The description case significance specifies how the capitalization of the string value should be handled, e.g., is it case sensitive or is it case insensitive. If the data has more specific capitalization rules, a new concept would need to be created to represent it.

row.entry: Assumes the description is dependent on capitalization
Value which designates character as not sensitive for a given description

section.para:
Revisiting the examples provided in section 3.2, the following representations and/or gaps were identified: Case Significance Example
Example Description
Example 1: SNOMED CT® From the SNOMED CT® export, the caseSignificanceID can be represented using the Case Significance child Concept. Specifically, in this scenario, Description Not Case Sensitive would be used.
Example 2: LOINC® In the LOINC® export file, there is no requirement to enforce case sensitivity on the long common name during a search, hence Description Not Case Sensitive would be used to represent its case significance.
Example 3: RxNorm In the RxNorm export file, the Tallman synonym specifically incorporates certain capital letters with a particular purpose, thus Description Case Sensitive would be used to represent its case significance.
Example 4: LIDR In the LIDR Data, there is no requirement to enforce case sensitivity during a search, hence Description Not Case Sensitive would be used to represent its case significance.
No new concepts would need to be created since the above Description Case Significance can be represented with what already exists in Tinkar.

section.title: Field 4: Description Type
section.para: The description type field is assigned to determine the type of description the string represents about that component. For example, the Fully Qualified Name is the main way a component is referred to. The Regular Name is any other common way or synonym referring to that concept. The Definition Description Type can be used to give a definition to any concept. If none of the description types below represent the description specific to the data set, a new concept would be created under Description Type to represent the new type of data.

row.entry: Specifying what type of description it is (i.e., is it fully qualified or regular and etc.)
Semantic value describing the description type for the description pattern is a definition
Fully qualified name is a description that uniquely identifies and differentiates it from other concepts with similar descriptions
There may be descriptions/synonyms marked as “regular.”

section.para:
Revisiting the examples provided above, the following representations and/or gaps were identified: Description Type Examples
Example Description
Example 1: SNOMED CT® From the SNOMED CT® export file, typeId is represented using one of the Description Types. Specifically, Synonym is represented using the Tinkar Regular Name Description Type.
Example 2: LOINC® From the LOINC® export file, the long common name can be represented using the Fully Qualified Name Description Type.
Example 3: RxNorm From the RxNorm export file, considering the list of Tinkar Description Types above (Fully Qualified Name, Regular Name, etc.), none of them directly represent the Tallman Synonym. Given that the Tallman Synonym is specifically used to emphasize capitalizing certain portions, a new Concept is created as a child Concept under Description Type. This Concept is termed "Tallman Synonym".
Example 4: LIDR From the LIDR Data, only the Model is given to represent the Name of the Device. So in this case the Fully Qualified Name Description Type would be used.
One new concept was created to represent the Tallman synonym for RxNorm. Otherwise, for SNOMED and LOINC®, no new concepts were created.

section.title: Determine Identifier Semantics
section.para: The Identifier Semantics are used to assign unique identifiers to components that point to outside data sources in which the identifier is used. For example, SNOMED CT® Identifiers and LOINC®ID’s that can be assigned to concepts. The Identifier Pattern and children concepts are shown below.

row.entry: An identifier that is used to label the identity of a unique component.
The literal string value associated as the ID.

section.para: To understand how this has been done before, examples of terminology snippets from SNOMED CT®, LOINC®, RxNorm, and LIDR are provided below. As the following sections walk through modeling the Identifier Semantic, these snippets will be referred to as examples for how to model certain fields.

section.title: Example 1: SNOMED CT®
section.para: The example in the below screenshot, shows a row SNOMED CT® data that will be used to show how the data set was represented using the Identifier Semantics.
Source: https://confluence.ihtsdotools.org/display/DOCRELFMT/4.2.1+Concept+File+Specification

section.title: Example 2: LOINC®
section.para: The example in the below screenshot, shows a row LOINC® data that will be used to show how the data set was represented using the Identifier Semantics.
Source: https://LOINC®.org/search/?t=1&s=7364-3.

section.title: Example 3: RxNorm
section.para: The example in the below screenshot, shows a row RxNorm data that will be used to show how the data set was represented using the Identifier Semantics.
Source File: https://lhncbc.nlm.nih.gov/RxNav/news/RxNorm-in-OWL.html

section.title: Example 4: LIDR
section.para: The example in the below screenshot, shows multiple rows in LIDR Data all corresponding to one Device. This data will be used to show how the data set was represented using the Identifier Semantics.

section.title: Field 1: Identifier Source
section.para: The Identifier source is a unique identifier representing the data source it comes from, such as SNOMED CT® or LOINC®. In cases where a data set is being represented for the first time in Tinkar, the source most likely will not exist yet and a concept will need to be created for it.

row.entry: A universally unique identifier that uniquely represents a concept in Tinkar

section.para: Revisiting the examples outlined in Section 3.3, the following representations and/or gaps were identified:

entry.emphasis: From the SNOMED CT® export file, given that the ID is not a UUID
, a new Concept is needed. This Concept, referred to as "SNOMED CT® Identifier Source", becomes a child Concept of Identifier Source. The Semantic Field Value references this newly created Concept.

row.entry: From the LOINC® export file, absence of an Identifier Source like in Example 1 exists. Thus, creation of a new "LOINC® Number" Concept under Identifier Source is needed, and used for the Semantic Field Value.

entry.para: From the RxNorm export file, assignment of two different Identifiers to the Concept results in two separate Identifier Semantics. One Semantic references the RxNorm CUI, while the other references the SNOMED CT® ID

listitem.para: In the case of the RxNorm CUI, creation of a new Concept under Identifier Source is required, named "RxNorm CUI". This becomes the Semantic Field Value for the first Identifier Semantic.
Regarding the SNOMED CT® ID, a new Concept needs creation, or utilization of the Concept from Example 1 would be used if it was previously created in the model.

row.entry: From the LIDR Data, the specific Issuing Agency and Jurisdiction have been combined to signify the source of the Name ID assigned. Thus, creation of a new “GS1_US FDA” Concept under Identifier Source is needed, and used for the Semantic Field Value.

section.para: In these examples, each example needed a new concept to represent the Unique Identifier.

section.title: Field 2: Identifier Value
section.para: The identifier value is the string representation of the Identifier, usually a random integer. Revisiting the examples provided in section 3.3, the following representations and/or gaps were identified:

row.entry: From the SNOMED CT® export file, the literal string value representing the ID column “413839001” is used for the field value.
From the LOINC® export file, the literal string value representing the LOINC_NUM column “7364-3” is used for the field value.

entry.para: From the RxNorm export file, in the previous example, 2 fields were created using 2 semantics. The string value representing each ID would be used to represent the field value.

row.entry: From the LIDR Data file, the literal string value representing the DI (Device Identifier “00382904453619” will be the field value

section.title: Determine Stated Definition Semantics
section.para: The Stated Definition Semantic represents the unique relationships that define a concept. This can be difficult to model against because it requires the determination of which data elements can go into the existing stated definition vs which elements will need new/ different patterns and semantics.

In this step, the properties of concepts that need to be represented make the concept unique, i.e., what are the underlying properties that make one concept in the model different from another, need to be identified.
The stated definition pattern is represented below along with the meaning and purpose concepts.

table.title: Stated Definition Meaning and Purpose Concepts

row.entry: The semantic meaning for the EL++ patterns
The semantic value describing the purpose of the stated and inferred terminological axioms.
The stated relationships that uniquely define a concept in EL++ description logic.
A display field that references a graph obtained from an undirected tree by replacing each undirected edge by two directed edges with opposite directions.

section.para: In cases where the data set is predefined, like SNOMED CT® or RxNORM, the OWL Description Logic String is provided which is used and transformed into the EL++ Stated Terminological Axioms. When creating a new model, the following properties of EL++ Terminological Axioms must be investigated to see how to describe the uniqueness of the concepts being modeled.
The stated definition child concepts are listed below.

row.entry: A set of relationships that indicate something has an implication. Not necessarily or sufficient but implicated.
A set of relationships that is always true of a concept.
A set of relationships that are non-defining and are not used by a description logic classifier.
A set of relationships that differentiate a concept and its subtypes from all other concepts. A concept that contains at least one set of necessary and sufficient conditions is considered defined.
An association between a set of attribute or axiom value pairs that causes them to be considered together within a concept definition or post-coordinated expression.

It is an abstract representation of a high-level role for a therapeutic medicinal product; the concepts are not intended to describe a detailed indication for therapeutic use nor imply that therapeutic use is appropriate in all clinical situations.

Refers to a concept that represents a particular kind of relationship that can exist between two entities. It defines the specific function or responsibility that one entity plays in relation to another.
The Concept referred to by the is-a axiom relationship or the axiom role relationship

section.para: To understand how the Stated Definitions Semantic has been modeled, examples of terminology snippets from SNOMED CT®, LOINC®, RxNorm, and LIDR are provided below. As the following sections walk through modeling the Stated Definitions Semantic, these snippets will be referred to as examples for how to model certain fields.

section.title: Example 1: SNOMED CT®
section.para: The example in the below screenshots, shows SNOMED Axiom example and then the Axiom expression that will be used to show how the data set was represented using the Stated Definitions Semantics.

Source: https://browser.LOINC®snomed.org/?perspective=full&conceptId1=413839001&edition=MAIN/LOINC®/2023-10-15&release=&languages=en SNOMED CT® Axiom Example for OWL Expression
SNOMED CT® Example OWL Expression

section.title: Example 2: LOINC®
section.para: LOINC® does not have OWL String representation. However, the following information shown below shows the data from LOINC® that was used to represent LOINC® using the Tinkar Stated Definitions Semantics.
Source: https://LOINC®.org/search/?t=1&s=7364-3

section.title: Determine Description Logic
section.para: Description logic is an attempt to represent and characterize classes of objects and the relationships between them. SNOMED CT, for example, uses description logic that corresponds to the EL++ language to define Stated and Inferred relationships and axioms.

listitem.para: Given that all source files differ, not all contain OWL Description Logic. (If they do contain an OWL Description Logic String, it should be utilized to avoid manually creating another string.)

section.para: Revisiting the examples provided in section 3.4, the following representations and/or gaps were identified:

entry.para: Utilization of the owlExpression column allows for the representation of the field using the Tinkar description logic. This string can be imported using EL++ Description Logic, leading to the generation of Stated Axioms.
LOINC® lacks an OWL String representation unless SNOMED CT®-LOINC® collaboration files are used, but these files lack completeness. Documentation reveals six main parts comprising a LOINC® Code

Part definitions from LOINC® are treated as "Roles" in the stated definition. "Role Type" corresponds to one of the six parts above. "Role Value" corresponds to the Concept representation of the value

listitem.para: To represent the data in the Stated Definitions Semantics, create a new Concept for each main LOINC® Part, and a new Concept for each unique value for each of the six parts so they can be assigned in the LOINC® Code Role

In addition to these six parts, there needs to be an “Is A” relationship to designate the parent Concept. In the SNOMED CT®-LOINC® Collaboration, all LOINC® Concepts are listed as a child of “Observable Entity”. So all LOINC® Codes will have an “Is A -> Observable Entity” relationship.

entry.para: In the RxNorm OWL release file, the OWL Syntax literal string row can be used to represent the Tinkar description logic field in the Stated Definitions Semantics.
LIDR does not have an OWL String representation so one must be created based on properties that uniquely define a device. Based on the Data Provided, there are:

These are treated as different “Roles” in the stated definition. “Role Type” corresponds to whomever the device was “Manufactured By” or “Labeled By”. The “Role Value” will be the Concept representing the Manufacturer or Labeler.

listitem.para: To represent the data in the Stated Definition Semantics, create a new Concept for each unique Manufacturer and Labeler so they can be assigned to the device

In addition to these two parts, there needs to be an “IsA” relationship to designate the parent Concept. To create device Concepts in the LIDR Data, a new Concept “Device” is created. Now all the Device Concepts will have an “Is A -> Device” relationship.

section.title: Example 4: LIDR
section.para:
The example in the below screenshot, shows the LIDR Data file that is used to show how the data was represented using the Stated Definitions Semantics.
LIDR Test Kit Device Example

section.title: Example 3: RxNorm
section.para: The example in the below screenshot, shows the RxNorm OWL file that isfigur used to show how the data was represented using the Stated Definitions Semantics.
Source File: https://lhncbc.nlm.nih.gov/RxNav/news/RxNorm-in-OWL.html

section.title: Create New Patterns
section.para: Once the current patterns are analyzed and representation using Tinkar is determined, there may be some outlying data that still needs to be extended into new Patterns in the Tinkar model. In this section, the steps for creating new patterns will be reviewed.

section.title: Filter for Data Elements associated to Concepts
section.para: Start by filtering data elements that are associated with the concept being modeled first. In other words, start with only the data elements that are associated to the concept being modeled and are not describing other data elements in the file rather than the concept itself. Because semantics refer/point to any component (any concept, pattern, or semantic), start with the patterns that refer/point to the concepts being modeled.

section.title: Example 1: SNOMED CT ®
section.para: In SNOMED there are descriptions and dialects. Descriptions are the patterns/semantics that are created and modeled first since they point to the actual concepts (semantic referring to a concept) themselves while Dialects refer/point to those Descriptions (semantic referring to a semantic).

section.title: Example 2: LOINC ®
section.para: In LOINC®we have a data element for STATUS. This directly describes an attribute to a LOINC®Concept. However there are additional data elements: STATUS_REASON, STATUS_TEXT, and CHANGE_REASON_PUBLIC. These 3 additional data elements don’t directly describe attributes of the LOINC®Concept itself, but are descriptive attributes of the STATUS.

section.title: Group by Similar Data Elements
section.para: Data fields with similar elements should be grouped together. Meaning, that elements that seem similar purposes and occur at the same frequency should be grouped together in a Pattern. They do not always have to have the same values across concepts. Once the related concepts are represented, these groupings are going to become new patterns.

section.title: Example 1: RxNorm
section.para: In RxNorm, HUMAN_DRUG and PRESCRIBABLE are two data elements that are closely related and seen together, but it’s not expected for them to occur with a field like VET_DRUG.

listitem.para:
In this case to add these 3 data elements, there would need to be 2 different patterns
HUMAN_DRUG + PRESCRIBABLE
VET_DRUG

section.title: Example 2: LIDR
section.para: In LIDR we have data elements like the Instrument Equipment Device, all six LOINC®parts (Component, Property, Time, System, Scale, and Method), and a Test Ordered and Test Performed LOINC®Code. The Instrument Equipment Device is the only data elements that can sometimes not exist in the cases of a take home test for example. So, we need a separate pattern for this data element and add a semantic to depending on if there is data present or not.

For the other six LOINC®parts and the two LOINC®Codes, if we look at the occurrences of them, we see that there are 4 of the parts (Property, Time, Scale, and Method) as well as the Test Ordered LOINC®Code that always exist once. For the remaining elements (System, Component, and Test Performed LOINC®Code), they can exist one or more times with different values for the same test. Because of this the design needs to be able to account for these situations and relationships so they are separated into two different patterns: the Diagnostic Device Pattern, and the Test Performed Pattern.

section.title: Determine Field Types
section.para: Once the new properties are grouped into the new patterns that need to be modeled, each data element will be treated as a field type. For each field, it needs to be determined how to represent the field in the model. A list of field types is below:

row.entry: A display field type that references a concept ID.
A display field that references an ordered list of Concept IDs.
A display field that references an unordered list of Concept IDs.
A display field that references a di-graph whose edges are ordered pairs of vertices. Each edge can be followed from one vertex to another vertex.
A display field that references a graph obtained from an undirected tree by replacing each undirected edge by two directed edges with opposite directions.
Represents values as high-precision fractional values.
A data type that represents some range of mathematical integers
A sequence of characters, either as a literal constant or as a variable. Strings could be used to represent terms from code systems or URLs, textual definitions, etc.

section.para: The most common field types to use are the Component Field, Component Set Field, and String Field. Things to consider:

listitem.para: If it’s a unique element that can vary significantly between concepts and rarely has a chance of two concepts having the same value, then it should be treated as a String or something similar.

If the value for the data element might be common across different concepts that are being modeled, than it should be considered to make that value its own concept and treat this field as a component field that’s going to have a value of that concept.

If there could be multiple values for the data element that can be shared or common across different concepts, then a Component Set Field can be used, and all the values can be modeled as different concepts and be in the “set”.

section.title: Example 1: Diagnostic Device Pattern
section.para: For this example, Laboratory InVitro Diagnostic Repository (LIDR) is used to explain how to approach creating new patterns. Starting by grouping together similar concepts as outlined in Section 2.6.1, there are 5 data elements that can be grouped together and applied to a Device concept.

Together they describe a Device concept in terms of it being a Diagnostic Device in which a Test is ordered. The new pattern's meaning and purpose is to show how a test being ordered for a diagnostic purpose should be coded in a health system. The field values are LOINC®Parts that describe the properties of the device.

When looking at the Field Types for the 5 data elements, they are all LOINC®Parts. In defining a Test that would get ordered and have a LOINC®Code assigned, there would only be 1 possible code which would translate to one possible value for each property. It is possible to re-use these concepts created by the LOINC®import and treat each field type as concept fields and point to the corresponding concepts in the semantic values. The resulting pattern format is shown below. In this example, a new concept was created called “Test Ordered” to assign as the meaning and purpose of the field and the pattern itself. The others assigned to the meaning and purpose can be pulled from the LOINC®Import.

section.title: Example 2: Test Performed Pattern
section.para: For this next example, a pattern was needed to describe the properties of a test being performed in LIDR. These properties are not specific to the device like in the Diagnostic Device Semantic but are properties of a test being performed by that device. Therefore, this semantic would be a semantic of a diagnostic device semantic, not of the device concept. When looking at it in this manner there could be multiple different tests being performed for a single ordered test. Therefore, there could be multiple Test Performed semantics to a single Diagnostic Device semantic.
When looking at the LIDR Information Requirements, the data elements to include in this pattern/semantic, the following fields were analyzed:

These data elements all describe how a test being performed in a health system should be properly coded. Since there is only one test performed per semantic, the Test Performed and Analyte Fields are treated as Concept Fields. There is only one concept value they should point to. However, for Targets and Specimen, there could be multiple possible concepts each describing a case for how to properly code the test. For these fields component set fields are used. The resulting pattern format created is shown below.

In this example, a new concept for each unique meaning and purpose did not exist so they would be created. Additionally, when creating a semantic of this pattern, all Field Values must be created before assignment (Analyte, Target, Specimen). The Test Performed Values reference LOINC®Codes that are available through importing LOINC.

section.title: Build Data Model and Starter Data

listitem.para: The Data Model is created using a modeling tool, mapping out the patterns, semantics, and concepts
Examples of current data models will be added here with descriptions.

section.title: Validating Models
section.para:
To ensure the creation of a stable and reliable model, each model must go through a validation process. The validation process includes two key roles:
Domain Subject Matter Experts (SMEs) who can provide critical feedback based on their specialized knowledge.

listitem.para: Tinkar Reference Modelers the people who initially build and document the model they create and additional modelers who can provide insight on ways to reuse current Tinkar components and be sure that any components that are reused, do so correctly.

section.para: The ultimate goal of this validation process is to achieve consensus on a stable model that all relevant parties agree upon, providing a solid foundation that ensures the model's accuracy and reliability for future developments.

There are three key steps when initiating the validation process: Peer review sessions, reviewing the model with the domain SME(s) and having review cycles, and coming to a group consensus on the final state of the model.

When the initial model is complete, modelers should work to collect and create documentation of the model. This documentation should include the logical data model drawing and documentation of all modeling decisions including Tinkar Patterns, Concepts, and Semantics that were reused and new Concepts, Patterns, and/or Semantics that were created. Rationale behind the decisions made should also be included. They should also work with other modelers to have peer review sessions to discuss the modeling decisions and rationale and come to agreed upon decisions about the model.

Once the initial model is complete, documentation is gathered, and the model has been peer reviewed, the modelers should review the model with the domain SME(s). The domain SME(s) should ensure the information requirements are met and the information is modeled in an agreed upon way. All rationale for decisions, any questions the modelers may have, and also possible options to how to model certain things should be given to the domain SME(s) to review.

Feedback gathered from the domain SME(s) should be captured and incorporated into the model. The modelers should then review the model again with the SMEs. The feedback process may continue to go back and forth for some time, but eventually when all feedback has been discussed and implemented where applicable, the model should be finalized, and all documentation of the changes and history of the model should be shared.

section.title: Model Documentation
section.para: Throughout the modeling process, modelers should capture documentation that describes the rationale for decisions made when modeling, create the starter data set, and create the logical data model. Table 24 contains descriptions for the different types of artifacts modelers should be able to provide once the modeling is complete:

row.entry: Documentation that was captured during the modeling process that helps explain the reasoning behind modeling decisions, any assumptions made, and the decisions made for fields in the data set that are being represented using Tinkar should be captured.
A list of any new Tinkar components that should be created to represent the data set.
A logical model representation of any new patterns/semantics/concepts.

entry.para: Relating to or involving data which is structured and tagged according to its meaning or intention, allowing it to be read directly by computers.

row.entry: Semantic, adj. meanings, etymology and more | Oxford English Dictionary (oed.com)
Logical Observation Identifiers, Names, and Codes
Systematized Nomenclature of Medicine Clinical Terms
Specifies that a description is acceptable, but not preferred within a language or dialect.
Concept used to represent a status for components that are active.
Concept used to represent a status for components that are canceled
Value for the description language dialect

A display field type that references a Concept ID.

Specifies how to handle the description text interms of case sensitivity

Specifying what type of description it is i.e. is it fully qualified or regular and etc.
The Semantic meaning for the EL++ Patterns
A path that specifies that the components are currently under development

row.entry: A display field that references a di-graph whose edges are ordered pairs of vertices. Each edge can be followed from one vertex to another vertex.

An identifier Pattern is used to identity a Concept which containts the identifier source and the actual value

A set of assets under version control that can be managed distinctly from other assets. Paths “branch” from other paths when established, and can be “merged” with other paths as well.

chapter.title: Archive
chapter.para: From the OWL Expressions, a set of stated relationships or axioms are automatically created through a reasoner. An alternative to having the description logic string can be to simply create the stated definition axioms inside of a Tinkar application like Komet directly. Here are the Stated Definition Axioms for each example:

listitem.para: Add an Is-A relationship to "Observable Entity”
Role Value would be “Festuca elatior Ab.IgG”
